title: Relates to piggyback contracts for the provision of transportation services for school districts
summary: Relates to piggyback contracts for the provision of transportation services for school districts; defines the term "piggyback contract".

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2755

TITLE OF BILL:

An act
to amend the education law, in relation to piggyback contracts for school
district transportation services

PURPOSE:

This Bill would allow school districts to share transportation
services for students living on shared transportation routes by
entering into a joint contact with another school district and that
school district's transportation contractor, a practice referred to
as a "piggyback contract."

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Paragraph h(2) of subdivision 25 of section 1709 of the education law
allows the board of education to enter into a "piggyback contract"
with another school district provided that the contract will result
in savings to the school district. In order for a school district to
be able to enter into a "piggyback contract," the school district
which they would like to contract with. (1) must already be providing
transportation to its own students through an existing contract with
a private transportation contractor, (2) the school district desiring
to enter into a "piggyback contract" must also enter into a contract
with the private transportation contractor and each school district
involved and (3) all school districts involved must abide by the
terms and conditions of the existing transportation contract.

JUSTIFICATION:

As the law stands now, a school district will frequently travel
through other school districts in the process of transporting their
students to and from school. Many times they will pass by students in
other districts who are going to the same school, but are transported
by their own school district. This practice results in excess cost to
the State because school districts are duplicating services when one
bus could pick up multiple students in more than one district. This
legislation promotes efficiency and savings by allowing school
districts to share transportation costs.

PRIOR LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

2009-10, S.1370; 2007-08, S.7615.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

None

EFFECTIVE DATE:

Immediately, with provisions.
